title: Mum who bought abortion pills for daughter acquitted after landmark law reform
text:
Pro-choice protesters on Monday, when Northern Ireland decriminalised abortion and made same-sex marriage legal (Picture: PA)

A mother who has faced prosecution for six years for buying online abortion pills for her teenage daughter has been formally acquitted after landmark reform in Northern Ireland.

A judge directed a jury at Belfast Crown Court today to find the woman not guilty.

The mother, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had been facing two counts of procuring and supplying the abortion drugs with the intent to procure a miscarriage, contrary to the 1861 Offences Against the Person Act.

That 19th-century legislation fell away at midnight on Monday when abortion was decriminalised.

Despite the law being repealed, Judge David McFarland said he was required to go through the legal formalities and swear in a jury.

This morning, prosecutors offered no evidence in court, which is when the judge told the jury of eight men and four women to enter a not guilty finding.

Speaking of her relief at the verdict, the mother said: ‘My emotions are all over the place and I find it hard to put into words how I am feeling.

That 19th-century legislation fell away at midnight on Monday (Picture: Getty)

‘For the first time in six years I can go back to being the mother I was, without the weight of this hanging over me every minute of every day and I can finally move on with my life.

‘I am so thankful that the change in the law will allow other women and girls to deal with matters like this privately in their own family circle.’

Her solicitor Jemma Conlon, of Chambers Solicitors, added: ‘Today is a day of immense relief for my client, who now finds herself free from the burden of this prosecution that has been in her life for six years.

‘It is a day that she will forever remember and a day that allows her to finally move on with her life privately without anguish and criminalisation.’

Parties were held across Northern Ireland on Monday night when the law officially changed at midnight, deciminalising abortion and making same-sex marriage legal.

LGBT celebrations in Belfast after the abortion and same sex marriage laws were reformed (Picture: Getty)

In Belfast, celebrations at the LGBT-friendly Maverick Bar were said to be ‘euphoric’.

The legal reforms were voted in at Westminster in the summer and the first same-sex weddings are expected to take place in February 2020.

The Democratic Unionist Party had attempted to table legislation to halt the abortion reform by gathering the Northern Ireland Assembly in Belfast for the first time in two years on Monday.

But their attempt fell at the first hurdle when outgoing speaker Robin Newton ruled the bill could not be considered until a new speaker was elected.
